article_html:
State water regulators say Californians conserved little water in March and local officials were not aggressive in cracking down on waste.

The update was presented on Tuesday to the state water resources control board as it considers sweeping restrictions to protect water supplies in the drought.

Related: California drought brings sound of silence to baked, barren farms

A survey of local water departments shows water use fell less than 4% in March compared to the same month in 2013.

Overall savings have been only about 9% since last summer, even though Governor Jerry Brown set a voluntary 20% target.

Brown is now ordering mandatory conservation. Regulators are considering rules to set water reduction targets of as much as 36% for some communities.

The board is also tracking enforcement of water rules. Most communities reported sending fewer than 20 warnings in March.

Last month, California’s water board said residents saved less water in February than in any other month since it began tracking conservation efforts last summer.

The figures then showed a water use reduction of just 3% in February compared with 2013 figures, dismal savings that came after the driest January on record in the state.
